node.title: How Hanif Abdurraqib Cuts Through the Noise
node.alt: “I’m not trying to be aloof,” Hanif Abdurraqib said. “My superpower is that I mind my own business.”
node.description: He is a National Book Award finalist for “A Little Devil in America,” but he has more books to write, more projects to take on and more s’mores to research.
node.content: ["COLUMBUS, Ohio \u2014 He received a MacArthur \u201cgenius\u201d grant in September. A week later, he was named a finalist for the National Book Award for his essay collection \u201cA Little Devil in America.\u201d But even though he is grateful for the accolades, Hanif Abdurraqib prefers to stay a bit removed from it all.", "He lives in this city where he grew up, not far from his old neighborhood and the people who knew him before he had written a word. \u201cI have a really small window of what I can let into my world, because my world is already so crowded with my own whimsical interests,\u201d he said, wrapped in a blanket in front of his house on a chilly afternoon last month.", "\u201cI\u2019m not trying to be aloof. My superpower is that I mind my own business,\u201d Abdurraqib added, a smile creeping into the center of his beard. \u201cAnd I actually think that helps my productivity more than anything.\u201d", "Abdurraqib, 38, is a music guy who came up in the punk scene, a sneakerhead with 132 pairs and an athlete who played soccer in high school and college \u2014 he taught his dog, Wendy, to kick the ball back and forth with him during the pandemic. He buys himself a bouquet of flowers every Saturday to put on his dining room table.", "What he is not is someone who always dreamed of being a writer. He came to it in his early 20s, writing for punk zines, he said, and it became something of a balm around the time he dropped out of Capital University.", "That period was a struggle, Abdurraqib said. He stole, skipped out on a warrant and landed in jail a few times. At one point, he was evicted, and for two months, he slept in a storage unit, showering at a YMCA during the day. At night, as quietly as possible to avoid detection, he would write.", "\u201cI did it to kind of take my mind off of survival,\u201d he said. \u201cI had this little portable light that I would use, but it wasn\u2019t because I was pursuing some grand career writing. It was to take my mind off the fact that this was the place I had to sleep.\u201d", "Abdurraqib has been open about some of his other struggles, as well. In \u201cA Little Devil in America,\u201d which Random House published in March, he weaves memoir through studies of Black performers, including the singer Merry Clayton, whose voice ripped through the song \u201cGimme Shelter\u201d by the Rolling Stones. Toward the end of the book, in an essay called \u201cOn Times I Have Forced Myself Not to Dance,\u201d he describes moments of deep depression. \u201cI remember, most of all, how my brother \u2014 larger than me in every way \u2014 held me while I cried in his arms and did not speak at all,\u201d he wrote, \u201cnot even to reassure me that things were going to be fine. Rather, in silence, to help me understand that things were not fine, but this was him, dragging me back from the brink. Holding me until the ledge became solid ground again.\u201d", "A few years later, with his life a bit more settled, Abdurraqib found poetry. Columbus has a vibrant literary scene, and pre-pandemic, Abdurraqib said, you could find a poetry open mic just about every night.", "He describes himself as an isolationist by nature, so slam poetry \u2014 a competition that takes place on a stage in front of a chatty audience \u2014 was not necessarily built for him. \u201cWhat I came to love about poetry slam,\u201d he said, \u201cwas the real-time editing that can happen in the room where you\u2019re performing, because you hear an audience response in real time. You know, these affirmative \u2018oohs\u2019 and \u2018ahhs\u2019 and snaps and delightful \u2018mmms.\u2019 And you get this feel for what\u2019s working, and get a sense for when you\u2019re holding an audience in your hands.\u201d", "His first book of poems, \u201cThe Crown Ain\u2019t Worth Much,\u201d was published by Button Poetry in 2016, not long after he started writing essays for MTV News like \u201cThe Night Prince Walked on Water\u201d and \u201cNina Simone Was Very Black.\u201d (\u201cIt is easy to be black and non-confrontational if nothing is on fire, and so it has never been easy to be black and non-confrontational,\u201d he wrote in the Nina Simone essay.)", "That work for MTV became the basis for a book of essays on music, culture and race in America, \u201cThey Can\u2019t Kill Us Until They Kill Us,\u201d published in 2017 by a small independent publisher in Columbus called Two Dollar Radio. Eric Obenauf, its editorial director, said the book has been its biggest hit, and that Abdurraqib has been instrumental in boosting the literary community in his hometown.", "\u201cEveryone rallies behind him here,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s such an occasion when he has a book out. All the bookstores are swamped with people. He really is this hero in town.\u201d", "That status was on display at a local coffee shop when a man, wearing a baseball hat with the state of Ohio stamped above the brim, approached Abdurraqib to offer a fist pound and some congratulations. (\u201cMark Sweeney, we went to Capital together,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve been seeing you everywhere. Nice job.\u201d) Abdurraqib swore he hadn\u2019t set the interaction up.", "Abdurraqib has also earned praise from organizers in local activist groups, like the Juvenile Justice Coalition and Black Queer & Intersectional Collective, who say the social consciousness in his work is something that shows up in his life, as well. He has been a regular at protests against police brutality, they said, and is happy to speak at rallies or to help fund-raise for groups he supports, sometimes cutting his own checks.", "Also, his face is on a building now. There\u2019s a brightly colored mural on East Main Street, not far from his house, that looks like it glows in the twilight.", "\u201cI\u2019m visible enough for three lifetimes at this point,\u201d Abdurraqib said. \u201cAt least for my own good, for what I can emotionally handle.\u201d", "When he says he likes to mind his own business, he explained, he\u2019s describing an effort to preserve his mental and emotional energy, keeping his focus tight because he has trouble just dipping a toe into something. Recently, for example, he realized he had never had s\u2019mores, and since he has a fire pit in front of his house (he had the grass taken out because he didn\u2019t want to mow it), he decided it was time to try them. So he Googled the best way to make to make s\u2019mores. Three hours later, he looked up and it was dark, he said, and he was still learning about the history of the graham cracker.", "\u201cThe best parts of my work hone that impulse and thread it through some, hopefully, nuanced and clear articulation of narrative,\u201d Abdurraqib said. \u201cBut the part that people don\u2019t see is the s\u2019mores situation.\u201d", "His criticism and essays are infused with this, but also with social commentary, memoir, pop culture, and always with poetry. Even the structure of his books sometimes take a poetic slant, like a chapter in \u201cA Little Devil In America\u201d called \u201cFear: A Crown,\u201d where the last line of each stanza echoes the first line of the next.", "\u201cLittle Devil\u201d is a book of celebration, but it began as one about the cultural appropriation of Black performance. Roughly halfway through writing it, Abdurraqib said, he realized he needed to focus instead on lifting up the work he found so thrilling.", "\u201cI\u2019m a really big Toni Morrison disciple,\u201d he said. \u201cOne thing Ms. Morrison always implored us to do as writers, as Black writers particularly, is to just see what happens if you don\u2019t center whiteness. Just see what happens, you know?\u201d", "But even the idea of decentering whiteness, Abdurraqib added later, gives whiteness too much credit. \u201cThe better question I was asking myself is, how can I celebrate the under-celebrated, or the uncelebrated, in new ways?\u201d", "Today, his varied interests are reflected in his many projects. He\u2019s working on a book about basketball. He\u2019s teaching at Butler University in Indianapolis. He has a website called 68to05, where he commissions essays about music for $300 a pop, and writes regularly for The New York Times Magazine. And last summer, he became an editor-at-large at Tin House, an independent publisher, where he\u2019ll acquire and edit about three nonfiction books a year. His first book, \u201cWhen They Tell You to Be Good\u201d by Prince Shakur, was announced this month.", "\u201cWriting is just something that I\u2019m so fortunate to be able to do,\u201d Abdurraqib said. \u201cBut it\u2019s kind of a thing where, well, I\u2019m not in a band. I didn\u2019t get to be the pro athlete. In the end, I stumbled upon something that I didn\u2019t know was a dream.\u201d"]
